Let \mathcal { C } be a cartesian category. Then an object B is exponentiable iff B ^{*} \colon \mathcal { C } \to { \mathcal { C } _{/{ B }}} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{B}.
Note that pullbacks over the terminal object 1 are products. Thus, we may assume that B ^{*} sends each object A \in \mathcal { C } to the first projection B \times A \to B.

Suppose that B ^{*} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{B}. B \times ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) can be expressed as \Sigma _{B} B ^{*}, where \Sigma _{B} is constructed in . By , \Sigma _{B} is left adjoint to B ^{*}. Thus, we may define ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} )^{B} := \Pi _{B} B ^{*}.

Conversely, suppose that B is exponentiable. Let us use the notation ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) ^{ \dag } to denote the exponential transpose. Let \mathcal { C } be a category with finite products. \mathcal { C } is said to be cartesian closed if every object is exponentiable.
